text:
I'm sure he might do something now that no one else would think of doing. For example, a year and a half ago, he shocked me when he thought about marrying that girl—what was her name? His landlady’s daughter?

“Did you hear about that?” asked Avdotya Romanovna.

“Do you think my tears, my pleas, my sickness, or even my possible death from sadness would have stopped him? No, he would have ignored all the problems. And yet, it’s not that he doesn’t love us!”

“He has never mentioned that to me,” Razu-mihin said carefully. “But I did hear something from Praskovya Pavlovna herself, and it was quite strange.”

“And what did you hear?” both women asked at the same time.

“Well, nothing too special. I just found out that the marriage didn’t happen because the girl died, and Praskovya Pavlovna didn’t like it at all. They say the girl wasn’t pretty; in fact, she was quite ugly and sickly. But she must have had some good qualities. It’s hard to understand why he liked her since she had no money, and he wouldn’t have cared about that anyway.”

“I’m sure she was a good girl,” Avdotya Romanovna said briefly.

“God forgive me, but I was actually glad when she died. Though I...”

**PAGE SUMMARY:** The conversation reveals the family's concern over a past failed marriage proposal and the complexities of love and sacrifice within their relationships.
